courses.title: Acroyoga Open House
courses.description: A curriculum for the acroyoga open house.

lessons.title: Movement Exploration
lessons.synopsis: Get into your body and develop fluidity
lessons.instructions:
On hands-and-knees explore shoulder movements:
- Shoulder push-ups
- Shoulder circles
- Unilateral shoulder circles
- Find your own shoulder/upper body movements

lessons.title: Plank Play
lessons.synopsis: Learn the principle: "The flyer holds the shape. The base balances."
lessons.instructions: One person goes into the top of push-up. The other person lifts the ankles. Drop one ankle at a time. The person on the ground has to keep the ankles together.

lessons.title: Leg tosses
lessons.synopsis: Connect the back to the ground for stability
lessons.instructions: One person lies on the back and raises their legs straight up. The other person tosses the legs left, right, forward, and back. The first person resists.

lessons.title: Cross Forearms on Legs
lessons.synopsis: Learn bone stacking
lessons.instructions: One person lies on their back and raises the legs straight up. The other person crosses the forearms in front of the chest. The other person places the forearms on the base's feet and adds their whole weight.

lessons.title: Hammock
lessons.synopsis: The easiest way to get into the air
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back with the shins up.
2. The flyer sits on the base's knees, facing away.
3. The base puts their feet behind the flyer's knee pits.
4. The flyer leans back until the flyer's shoulderblades rest on top of the base's hands.
5. The base straightens their legs.

lessons.title: "Table on Table"
lessons.synopsis: Learn bone stacking
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back with the knees on top of the hips and the arms on top of the shoulders.
2. The flyer places their palms on the shins of the base just below the kneecap.
3. The flyer places the first knee (same position as above) on top of the base's dominant hand.
4. The flyer slowly shifts the weight to lift the second leg onto the other base's hands.

The pair can now "walk," extend arms/legs at the same time, or open the knees/arms outside.

lessons.title: Bird Receiving
lessons.synopsis: Prepare for bird pose
lessons.instructions:
Important! Take your time to really receive well and controlled and for the flyer to maintain a plank throughout the movement.

1. The base puts their arms down along the side. The flyer walks up so that flyer toes meet the base's fingertips.

2. The base places the feet on the flyers hips. The middle of the balls of the feet should meet the pointy part of the hip bone.

3. The flyer maintains the plank pose while the base bends their knees.

- Bend the knees slowly to avoid scaring the flyer.
- Go progressively deeper.
- Practice controlling the speed and stopping point.

lessons.title: Bird Pose
lessons.synopsis: Learn the quintessential acroyoga pose
lessons.instructions:
1. Start with bird receiving.
2. Receive until the "hook point." That's when the base feels like they have the entire weight of the flyer.
3. The base scoops up the flyer into the air.

Focus on straight arms and legs!

lessons.title: King Throne aka Chair
lessons.synopsis: Feel like a Queen!
lessons.instructions:
1. The flyer stands with their feet next to the base's ears, facing away.

2. The base places their toes right below the butt on the thigh.

3. The flyer leans back until the "hook point" (the base feels the flyer's full weight on them).

4. The base presses the flyer up until the legs are stacked and the arms are stacked under the flyer's feet.

5. To come down, transition the hands back to the ankles. Be sure to let go off the flyer once on the ground to avoid tripping them.

lessons.title: High-Flying Whale
lessons.synopsis: A fun restorative pose
lessons.instructions:
1. The flyer places their feet next to the ears of the base, facing away.

2. The base reaches with their toes to the bra strap/heart rate monitor level on the flyer's back.

3. The flyer leans back.

4. The base graps the flyer's ankles and pushes them up on their feet.

5. Ask the flyer for a preferred foot angle to control the amount of back stretch.

Note: The stacked position in this pose is more like a suspension bridge. The arms and legs of the base are straight, but facing a bit away from each other.

courses.title: Argentine Tango
courses.description: Argentine Tango combines classical elegance and a deeply meditative connection between the partners.\n\nSessions available in LA: https://oxygentango.com

courses.title: Argentine Tango - MM
courses.description: Mitra and Stefan's original peer-to-peer tango curriculum from Oxygen

lessons.title: Mirror Game
lessons.synopsis: This exercise practices and introduces deep connection in leading/following.
lessons.instructions:
One person makes movements. The other copies them.

- Start with big, slow upper body movements.
- Work to more subtle movements.
- Switch lead.
- Switch lead without speaking.

Tips: 
- Find a place where there isn’t dance traffic.
- Ask the host to play lyrical music

lessons.title: Shadow Legs
lessons.synopsis: The upper body mirrors. The lower body shadows.
lessons.instructions:
- Play Mirror Game using big slow leg movements
- Work to smaller movements like side steps and weight changes
- Switch lead
- Show practice hold
- Walk forwards, backwards, sideways
- Show how lower body shadows while upper body mirrors
- Switch lead

Tips: 
- Ask them to “send” their embrace towards you
- Exaggerate the tone in the embrace
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: Side-By-Side
lessons.synopsis: Synchronized walking side-by-side. Builds on natural instinctual ability to walk through a space, lead and follow, which people usually lose when they are put into a formal dance situation.
lessons.instructions:
1. Walk side by side, arms around backs
2. Play with double time, half time and pauses
3. Switch the lead

Tips
- You don’t need to start on the same leg
- The idea is to take the same size steps at the same time
- Pausing (staying on one foot) vs weight shifts (marching in place)

Bonus!
- Play with a few really long pauses
- Tell them about the line of dance
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: First Figure
lessons.synopsis:
Boxy six count step that travels down line of dance. 

This exercise shows the rich possibilities of improvising with a basic pattern.
lessons.instructions:
1. Lead the step. It is a rectangular pattern that begins with a side step with leader’s left and follower’s right.
2. Add rock steps
3. Rotate it counterclockwise
4. Add pauses
5. Alter step size
6. Switch roles and do 1-5.

Tips: 
- Introduce syncing up
- Highlight inline vs. outside partner
- Explain FRONTALITY
- Backlead when you first switch roles
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: The Cross
lessons.synopsis: The 8-count salida with the follower’s cross.
lessons.instructions:
Steps: 
1. Demonstrate the Cross solo
2. Have them copy you
3. Lead them to the cross and resolution
4. Alternate between the Cross and the First Figure.
5. Have them lead it
6. Have them alternate between the two figures.

Tips
- Be sure they really transfer weight when they cross: explain free leg/standing leg
- Both partners hips should face each other at the cross
- Have the leader study the follower’s crossed legs, to see which leg to step with after the cross.

Bonus!
Explain the cross is a default for the follower. The follower does it unless the leader interrupts.
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: Forward Ocho
lessons.synopsis: How to do the forward ocho.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Demonstrate the Forward Ocho at the wall
2. Have them copy you
3. Explain the parts of the ocho: Extend, Step, Pivot, Extend
4. Repeat Forward Ochos in practice hold
5. Execute Forward Ochos from the Cross.
6. Learn exiting Forward Ochos to a side step

Tips
- Be sure they PIVOT FULLY before reaching to the next step
- Highlight: The follower’s part takes longer than the leader’s part
- Highlight: The far side of the follower becomes the near side

Bonus!
- Explain leader’s invitation: the embrace “talks” to one side of the follower’s body to invite an ocho
- When they lead, let them problem-solve how to exit the ocho.
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: Backward Ocho
lessons.synopsis: How to do the backward ocho
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Demonstrate the Backward Ocho at the wall
2. Have them copy you
3. Review the parts of the ocho: Extend, Step, Pivot, Extend
4. Repeat Backward Ochos in practice hold
5. Learn exiting Backward Ochos

Tips
- Have them stay super close to wall so they’re not falling
- Make sure they EXTEND backwards fully, before stepping
- Reinforce LEADER'S INVITATION
- Remind leader to focus on the follower’s body through whole pivot
- Highlight: The follower’s part takes longer than the leader’s part
- Highlight: The near side of the follower becomes the far side

Bonus!
- “Which Ocho?” Game: Side step, then have FOLLOWER choose
- “Which Ocho?” Game: Side step, then have LEADER invite
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: Parada Play
lessons.synopsis: The mechanics of Parada-Sandwich-Pasada. The movement has the effect of changing a Backward Ocho into a Forward Ocho.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead Backwards Ochos
2. Lead the Parada to the hugward side.
3. Talk them through the parts:
- Leader stops the ocho (Parada)
- Leader Sandwiches
- Leader Steps back
- Follower Sandwiches
- Follower steps over (Pasada)
- Forward Ochos and exit

Tips
- Explain that if feet touch we stop.
- Lower your body to stop the follower mid-ocho.
- Follower chooses the timing for when to step over.
- For both to be comfortable and Aligned, the embrace needs to be very flexible. 
- Explore when and where to adjust the arms.

Bonus!
- Explain adornments!
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: Tango Sentence
lessons.synopsis: How to travel down the line of dance using tango elements. This exercise brings together the previous elements. The idea is to find a feeling of flow as you do it.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Explain the structure of the sentence: Side step -> Backward Ochos -> The Cross -> Forward Ochos -> Side step
2. Zoom in on transition from Backwards Ochos to the Cross, doing it slowly several times.
3. Execute it several times with different numbers of Ochos.

Tips
- Stay in outside lane and travel downstream
- Leader faces outward toward walls/mirrors/tables
- Handward side of embrace points down line of dance
- It doesn’t matter which system the leader uses to get to the Cross.
- Point out how little the leader moves vs the follower.
- Leader should keep their body frontal to partner. To do this they need to switch feet on ocho exits.

Bonus!
- “How Many Ochos?” Game: Let them decide in advance how many ochos they’ll follow: ODD number of backwards ochos, EVEN number of forward ochos.
- Backleading this, while telling them verbally what to do with their feet, really helps a first-time leader
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: The Other System
lessons.synopsis: The difference between parallel (“normal”) system and the other system.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Explain Tango Figures are defined by what the FOLLOWER does. (The SAME figure can be done in many different ways, by the leader doing different footwork)
2. Review the Cross with them leading
3. Have them problem-solve and find a different way to do the same Figure
4. Teach the Secret Weight Shift.
5. Learn to do the Cross after a secret weight shift.

Tips
- During secret weight shift, the embrace should stay very still.
- Direct follower’s focus on what they feel, not what they see
- Leader’s footwork to the Cross is after secret shift is Left, Right.

Bonus!
- Explain parallel system vs crossed system nomenclature
- Quiz: How do we get from one system to the other? Answer: One person switches feet without the other.
- Explore: Which system are we in when we do Ochos? How did we get into it, how do we get out of it?
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: Soft Boleo
lessons.synopsis: New dramatic gateway between ochos.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Define boleo: turning a BACKWARDS pivot into a FORWARDS one (or vv)
2. Lead backward ochos
3. Lead change of pivot from backwards to forwards
4. Lead forward ochos
5. Switch roles

Tips
- Follower’s full back Extension makes boleo possible
- Follower keeps foot on the ground throughout extension and Pivot
- When they lead, timing’s key: boleo pivot is led at END of extension but BEFORE weight transfer

Bonus!
Try a forward boleo!
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: Turning Ochos
lessons.synopsis: Sculpting ochos into nooks and crannies.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead repeated forward ochos while turning clockwise (e.g., 2-3 ochos north, east, south, west)
2. Do it counterclockwise
3. Lead repeated backward ochos while turning clockwise
4. Do it counterclockwise
Switch roles and repeat

Tips
- Point out how different each pivot is
- Leader should give follower enough time for each pivot
- Leader should make space for the far side of the follower’s body

Bonus!
Dance in the context of a Tango Sentence
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: The Box
lessons.synopsis: Easy pattern with lots of variants to quickstart milonga.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead the box step, a six-count square pattern that starts w/leader retreating inline with right leg.
2. Occasionally add 1 or 2 extra steps hugward at the end (top) of the box. This ensures weight shifts are being accurately communicated.
3. Make the box step rotate clockwise
4. Switch roles.

Tips
- When they lead, be sure you can feel them leading the weight shifts
- Point out that the whole box step is in parallel system

Bonus!
Define basic terms: tanda, tango, milonga (the party), milonga (the music)
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: The Traspie
lessons.synopsis: Double time rhythm that adds energy and alertness.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead “testing the waters”: sending weight halfway into a side step then returning
2. Lead a weight change in place
3. Lead a retreating inline step
4. Repeat, and this time do an advancing outside-partner step after the weight change

Tips
- Slowly and clearly lead the weight change after the “testing the waters” - it is easily missed

Bonus!
Define traspie: three steps instead of one in the same timing, resulting in a double-time
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: Forward-Forward
lessons.synopsis: Big juicy relaxing steps for contrast.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead the first step of the Box, which is the first “forward” for the follower
2. Lead the follower forward again, this time outside-partner
3. Lead a side step hugward, turning a quarter turn
4. Lead a weight change
5. Repeat

Tips
- Point out that walking forward is nice contrast for followers, since they mostly walk backwards
- Remind them to land heels-first when walking forward
- Lead first two steps BIG and keep LOW; last two steps UP and SMALL
- To make room for follower’s second forward step outside-partner, leader’s first step should be like on a tightrope

Bonus!
When they lead, have them figure out how to start to it navigates (Answer: Start backwards!)
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: The Line
lessons.synopsis: Calmly going back and forth together in a slot.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead advancing outside-partner step (third step in Box)
2. Lead weight change
3. Lead retreating step inline
4. Lead weight change

Tips
- Basically shrinking both side steps of box, making them weight shifts
- When they lead, make sure they’re leading & reading the weight shifts

Bonus!
Make it rotate counterclockwise (change facing on weight shifts)
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: The Stair
lessons.synopsis: Zigzagging down line of dance together.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead advancing outside-partner step (third step in Box)
2. Lead weight change
3. Lead side step (top of the Box)
4. Lead weight change
5. Repeat

Tips
- Slow down and focus on each weight change, make sure these are being fully communicated
- When stepping side, the leader should land with weight a little forward

Bonus!
- Simon Says Game 1! Follower calls out “Box” or “Stair” and leader needs to switch to the new patter with the very next step.
- Simon Says Game 2! Pick threee missions in the Milonga ring. Follower calls out which one to do and the leader leads it next.
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: The Comb
lessons.synopsis: Varation on easy box that travels down line of dance.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead the first four steps of the box (three sides of the box, minus the top)
2. Repeat, and travel down the line of dance
3. Occasionally, add the box-top anytime, to make sure communication is happening

Tips
- The couple’s handward side should be pointed down line of dance, so the Comb travels continuously downstream

Bonus!
- Following the follower! The FOLLOWER decides when we switch from Box to Comb and the leader adapts to her choice.
graduationRequirements: They have mastered this lesson and are ready to teach it to others.

lessons.title: Embrace Breath
lessons.synopsis: Embrace and synchonize breathing with steps (inhale=pause, exhale=step) as you do the first two figures.
lessons.instructions:
To warm up, improvise for half a song with no embrace, then switch roles for the other half.

Walking side-by-side, one person sets pace and both pause on inhale, walk on exhale.

Same thing, this time try to extend the exhale by taking more steps.

Switch who’s setting the pace and do 3-4 again.

Review the First Figure. In practice hold, using just this material, let every shared inhale be a pause and every shared exhale be movement.

Switch roles.
graduationRequirements: Are they able to Follow the Follower?

courses.title: Best Practices for Working From Home
courses.description: An introduction to applied attention science to help self-employed and remote employees who work from home make the most of their time and optimize their environment

lessons.title: Attention and how it works
lessons.synopsis: Attention and how it works
lessons.instructions:
Explore: How is attention different from time?

Metaphors for attention as a limited resource - come up with a few. 

Distinction: Directed vs involuntary attention. Brainstorm examples of each.  

Definition: Directed attention fatigue and its symptoms. Exchange stories. 

Distinction: Soft fascination vs hard fascination. Brainstorm examples of each. 

Explore: Audit of current practice of “attention breaks,” how restorative they are. 

Shape a small experiment that will increase the restorativeness of the breaks you take.
graduationRequirements: Did they come up with a novel metaphor that accurately presents attention as a limited resource?
Did they explain the difference between soft fascination and hard fascination with novel examples from their life?
Did they explain the difference between directed and involuntary attention with novel examples from their life?
Did they make a list of the kinds of breaks they normally take and accurately classify them in terms of the types of attention and fascination they exhibit?
Were they able to give an example from their life about how directed attention works, what the symptoms are when it is fatigued, and what is needed to restore it?
Did they frame a specific experiment that will make their breaks more restorative through increasing soft fascination?

lessons.title: Beginnings that support attention
lessons.synopsis: Beginnings that support attention
lessons.instructions:
Thinking of your typical week, what are all the moments that feel like beginnings? 

Tell a story of a beginning (day, week, meeting, session, project...) that felt wholesome and helped you focus. 

Explore/brainstorm: What are the ingredients or qualities of a “good beginning”? Identify dimensions like light, time of day, timers, words, space, rituals, props... 

Go further and audit all the possible important micro beginnings you experience each day/week that you may have overlooked. 

Choose an important one and design how you will use it to align purpose and direction of attention. 

Thinking about the workweek as a whole, shape a small experiment that will allow you to benefit from the energy of beginnings.
graduationRequirements: Did they make a full list of all the moments in their week that feel like beginnings or micro-beginnings?
Did they tell a story of a beginning and explain why it supported their attention using vocabulary from lesson 1?
Did they identify what specific elements help create good beginnings for them?
Did they frame a concrete, doable experiment for their worklife that will help them create beginnings that support directed attention?

lessons.title: Work sessions worth something
lessons.synopsis: Work sessions worth something
lessons.instructions:
Explore: What is work? How do you know when you are doing work? 

Brainstorm: What are all the different kinds of things you do that are work? 

Distinction: unitasking vs multitasking. Brainstorm examples of each. 

Distinction: reflection vs rumination. Brainstorm examples of each. 

Tell the story of a work session or work project that felt productive and enjoyable. 

Definition: Flow state 

Identify: which of the flow state ingredients tends to be missing for you? Complete immersion in a task, a balanced challenge-skill level, clear goals, immediate feedback, a sense of control, minimal distractions, a loss of self-consciousness, altered perception of time, and intrinsic motivation.  

Thinking about the important work you do, shape a small experiment that will allow you to enter a flow state.
graduationRequirements: Did they make a full list of all the kinds of work they do?
Did they come up with novel examples from their life of unitasking and multitasking?
Did they come up with novel examples from their life of reflection and rumination?
Did they share a specific story/example of being in a flow state when work was productive and enjoyable?
Did they frame a concrete, doable experiment for their worklife that will help remove obstacles and enter into a flow state ?

lessons.title: Closures that remove brain drain
lessons.synopsis: Closures that remove brain drain
lessons.instructions:
Explore: What does it mean to get “complete” on a task or worksession? 

Brainstorm: What are all the different kinds of completion/incompletion you experience in your work/life

Explore/brainstorm: What are the ingredients or qualities of a “good completion”? Identify dimensions like words, gestures, sounds, songs, habits, tracking...

Identify how incompletion feels. What “incompletes” tend to distract, worry, or bother you the most? 

Mindsweep: Set a timer for 8 minutes and write down all the incompletes that are on your mind. Include everything, long term, short term, work, personal life

Choose a moment that tends to leave you feeling incomplete (e.g., end of a worksession, conversation, meeting, workday, week, project) and design an experiment to create a feeling of completion while tracking next-step tasks.
graduationRequirements: Did they share what completion and incompletion looks like with real examples from their own life?
Did they identify what are the specific ingredients of that help them feel complete with something?
Did they identify the most distracting incompletions they have?
Did they complete the mindsweep exercise using incompletes from all parts of their life?
Did they frame a concrete, doable experiment to reduce the distraction of an incomplete?

courses.title: Coding Interview Prep
courses.description: Prepare for DSA (Data Structures & Algorithm) coding interviews. Begin by reviewing fundamental data structures and algorithms. Then, hone your skills on commonly asked coding interview questions. This course is programming language agnostic.

lessons.title: Intro & Hello World
lessons.synopsis: Introduction to the Learning Labs and Hello World!
lessons.instructions:
(1) Start every mini-lesson with a short intro of each other.

(2) Provide an intro to the learning lab:
- Learn than teach
- Graduate only when you are ready
- The "Together Page" let's two people compare what they can teach each other. (How: Look up the other profile on the profile page and press the "together" button.)

(3) The learner shares their screen with their IDE and does a Hello World to ensure that everything is set up for shared coding in future mini-lessons.

(4) Answer any questions

Common Questions:---
Q: How do you prevent mentors from teaching wrong things?

A: First, before mentoring, another mentor has to graduate them for the particular lesson. Second, lessons are usually exercises or projects. So if the goal is to sort a string and the string doesn't sort right, you both know that the mentor didn't teach right.

Q: Why would anyone teach for free?

A: That's a common question that people have upfront. However, students who have tried it quickly embrace the teaching part because they are realizing that they are learning a lot from it. The learning part primes the information. However, the teaching (having to explain it and answer questions) really makes one get material.
graduationRequirements: Successfully shared the screen and ran Hello World

lessons.title: Big O Notation and Complexity Analysis
lessons.synopsis: Learn to classify algorithm efficiency using Big O notation and evaluate time/space trade-offs.
lessons.instructions:
(1) Introduce asymptotic performance.

(2) Review common Big O's and examples: O(k), O(log n), O(n),...

(3) Ask the student about the speed and space performance of common algorithms: Single loop, double loop, inserting into a linked list, binary search, different sort algorithms.

(4) Give the student a trick question where the code looks one way, but it calls a library method that changes the performance. (E.g. the code looks constant but the library method is linear.)
graduationRequirements: The student should confidently get the Big O notation correctly for at least three examples.

lessons.title: Problem-Solving Techniques (UMPIRE Method)
lessons.synopsis: Master a step-by-step approach to breaking down problems before coding, boosting clarity and confidence.
lessons.instructions:
(1) Introduce that interviewers look for how a coding problem is solved.

- Start by asking clarifying questions.
- Consider edge cases.
- Handle bad input.
- Match the problem to an algorithm.
- Discuss alternatives/improvements with the interviewer.
- After coding review the code and step through with sample values.
- ...

(2) Apply the concept by having the learner implement atoi (convert a string to an integer). Focus on how the learner handles the question, not the actual coding.

Note: Use itoa or similar for learners that repeat the lesson.
graduationRequirements: Thorough in discussing the problem before and after.

lessons.title: Implement An ArrayList
lessons.synopsis: Understand how an ArrayList works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have an ArrayList - a list structure that's backed by an array.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- add
- get
- remove

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.

Note: Actual library implementations ahve various optimizations like bucketing. You may discuss that if there is time.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement A Linked List
lessons.synopsis: Understand how linked list works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have a linked list - a list structure that provides constant time insertion.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- add
- get
- remove

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.

Note: If there is time, discuss variations like a double-linked list.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement A Hash Table/Map
lessons.synopsis: Understand how an hash table/map works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have a hash table or map - a structure that provides constant time lookup.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- add/put
- get
- remove

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.

(3) As there is time, discuss topics like key collision.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement A Stack
lessons.synopsis: Understand how a stack works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have a stack.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- push
- pop
- size

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.

Note: The learner can use a library method like an ArrayList, but not a Stack itself.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement A Queue
lessons.synopsis: Understand how a queue works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have a queue.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- push
- pop
- size

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement Binary Search
lessons.synopsis: Binary Search is a common solution that has to be adapted for special cases.
lessons.instructions:
(1) Ask the learner to implement binary search.

(2) Ask them to identify and step through to different cases.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_search
graduationRequirements: The learner can correctly implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Sorting 101: Quick Sort
lessons.synopsis: Implement quick sort to understand the basics of sorting
lessons.instructions:
(1) Ask the learner to implement quick sort. (Repeatedly sorting around a pivot point.)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quicksort
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Sorting 102: Merge Sort
lessons.synopsis: A basic algorithm that can be applied to in many different contexts
lessons.instructions:
Ask the learner to implement merge sort.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merge_sort
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Sorting 103: Insertion Sort
lessons.synopsis: Implementing insertion sort teaches a technique that's useful in specific cases.
lessons.instructions:
Ask the learner to implement insertion sort.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insertion_sort
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Tree 101: In-Order Traversal
lessons.synopsis: Implement in-order tree traversal
lessons.instructions: Ask the learner to implement in-order tree traversal: Given the root node of a tree, return an array of the values.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Tree 102: Pre-order Traversal
lessons.synopsis: Implement pre-order traversal of a binary tree.
lessons.instructions: Ask the learner to implement the pre-order traversal of a binary tree: Given the root note, return an array of values.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Tree 103: Insert Into A Binary Search Tree
lessons.synopsis: Implement insertion into a binary search tree
lessons.instructions:
(1) Ask the learner to implement insertion into a binary search tree.

(2) Discuss strategies for keeping the tree balanced.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Tree 104: Delete From A Binary Search Tree
lessons.synopsis: Implement how to delete a value from a binary search tree.
lessons.instructions:
Ask the learner to implement an algorithm to delete a value from a binary search tree.

Note: This can get tricky.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Greatest Common Divisor (GCD)
lessons.synopsis: The Euclidean Algorithm is a useful tool for problems that require using the GCD.
lessons.instructions:
(1) Ask the learner to discuss strategies on how to determine the GCD.

(2) Introduce the Euclidean Algorithm and why it works.

(3) Ask the learner to implement it.
graduationRequirements: The learner can code the algorithm within the given time.

levels.title: Arrays & Strings – Basics and Two-Pointer Patterns

lessons.title: Array Manipulation 101 - Remove Duplicates
lessons.synopsis: Build confidence with arrays
lessons.instructions:
(1) Ask the learner to solve "Remove duplicates from a sorted array."

https://leetcode.com/problems/remove-duplicates-from-sorted-array/description/
graduationRequirements: Can implement an optimal solution within the time constraint.

lessons.title: Array Manipulation 102 - Rotate An Array
lessons.synopsis: A Medium difficulty array problem
lessons.instructions:
Ask the learner to solve "Rotate an Array."

The learner may have to take this lesson twice. You may let the learner implement the bruteforce way the first time and ask for a more optimal solution the second time.

https://leetcode.com/problems/rotate-array/description/
graduationRequirements: Either can code a suboptimal solution within the time constraint or an optimal solution going a bit over time.

lessons.title: Array Manipulation 103 - Kadane's Algorithm
lessons.synopsis: Kadane's Algorithm is a swift trick for subarray problems.
lessons.instructions:
(1) Ask the learner to solve the "Maximum Subarray" problem.

https://leetcode.com/problems/maximum-subarray/description/

Note: Depending on how they are doing, you can guide them to figure out Kadaen's Algorithm or provide it.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_subarray_problem
graduationRequirements: Can solve the problem.
Demonstrate a solid grasp on Kadane's Algorithm.

lessons.title: String Pattern Matching 101 - Anagram
lessons.synopsis: Learn frequency maps as a common solution
lessons.instructions:
(1) Present the "Valid Anagram" coding problem.

https://leetcode.com/problems/valid-anagram/description/
graduationRequirements: Can solve the problem within the given time.

lessons.title: String Pattern Matching 102 - Palindrome
lessons.synopsis: Introduction to two-pointer solutions
lessons.instructions:
Present the problem to detect an palindrome.

https://leetcode.com/problems/valid-palindrome/description/
graduationRequirements: Can solve the problem within the given time.

lessons.title: Two-Pointer Technique
lessons.synopsis: Solve problems efficiently by moving two pointers through a structure, a key pattern for sorting, searching, and many array/string challenges.
lessons.instructions:
Present the problem to find two numbers in a sorted integer array that add up to a target sum.

https://leetcode.com/problems/two-sum-ii-input-array-is-sorted/description/
graduationRequirements: The learner can solve the problem within the given time.

lessons.title: Floyd's Turtoise And Hare Algorithm
lessons.synopsis: Using a slow and fast pointer is a very useful tool
lessons.instructions:
(1) Ask the learner to identify a cycle in a linked list.

(2) Guide them as needed towards Floyd's Turtoise And Hare algorithm.

(3) Ask the learner to implement it.

(4) Ask about the time complexity.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycle_detection
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Reverse A Linked List
lessons.synopsis: Warms up questions with linked lists.
lessons.instructions:
Given the head of a linked list, return the linked list reversed.

https://leetcode.com/problems/reverse-linked-list/description
graduationRequirements: The learner can code the solution within the given time.

lessons.title: Kid's With Greatest Number Of Candies
lessons.synopsis: A warm-up for array questions.
lessons.instructions:
Ask the question from Leetcode:

https://leetcode.com/problems/kids-with-the-greatest-number-of-candies/description
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Move Zeroes To The Back
lessons.synopsis: Warm-up for two-pointer problems.
lessons.instructions:
Ask the learner to move all the zeroes to the back of an integer array.

https://leetcode.com/problems/move-zeroes/description/

lessons.title: Find the highest altitude
lessons.synopsis: An easy warm-up for prefix sum questions
lessons.instructions:
Ask the learner to find the highest altitude. You are given in an array where each element has the altitude change to the previous altitude.

https://leetcode.com/problems/find-the-highest-altitude/description/
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Find The Difference Of Two Arrays
lessons.synopsis: Warm-up for hash map/set questions.
lessons.instructions:
Given two integer arrays, return the set of numbers that are unique in the first array and the set for of unique numbers of the second array.

https://leetcode.com/problems/find-the-difference-of-two-arrays/description/

lessons.title: Number Of Recent Calls
lessons.synopsis: Warms up problems with queues.
lessons.instructions:

https://leetcode.com/problems/number-of-recent-calls/description

lessons.title: Maximum Depth Of Binary Tree
lessons.synopsis: Warms up binary tree type questions.
lessons.instructions:
Given the root of a binary tree, return the max depth of the binary tree.

https://leetcode.com/problems/maximum-depth-of-binary-tree/description/
graduationRequirements: The learner can code the problem within the given time.

lessons.title: Counting bits
lessons.synopsis: Warming up dynamic programming questions.
lessons.instructions:
Ask the question: You are given an integer n. It means that we are looking at all the numbers from 0 to n (inclusive). However, we are not simply returning the number. We are returning the count of 1's of the number in binary form.

https://leetcode.com/problems/min-cost-climbing-stairs/description/

Note: There is a simple way to solve this. And there is an optimal solution in linear time. You probably should let the learner implement the simpler version and tell them about the optimal version later.

lessons.title: Intro To Recursion
lessons.synopsis: A quick intro into recursion
lessons.instructions:
(1) Explain the concept of recursion.

(2) Ask the learner to implement an algorithm that finds a Fibonacci number. (a + b = c; b + c = d...

(3) Ask the learner to implement an algorithm that calculates the factorial. (5! = 5 * 4 * 3 * 2 * 1)
graduationRequirements: The learner could implement the Fibonacci number
The learner could implement the factorial.

lessons.title: Intro To Memoization - Coin Change Problem
lessons.synopsis: Introduce Memoization/dynamic programming with the coin change problem.
lessons.instructions:
This is a didact problem. Let the learner try to solve the problem, then propose how to use a cache and recursion if necessary. The goal is to guide the learner towards understanding DP rather than simply solve the problem.


https://leetcode.com/problems/coin-change/description/
graduationRequirements: The learner has a good grasp of DP and how to apply it elsewhere.

lessons.title: House Robber (Medium)

lessons.title: Unique Paths (Medium)

graduationRequirements: The learner could implement the algorithm within the given time.

courses.title: Home barista
courses.description: The Four-Week Home Barista Course is designed to take you from espresso novice to confident home barista. In just four weeks, you'll master essential espresso-making skills, including pulling the perfect shot, frothing milk, and creating beautiful latte art. Each week focuses on a new set of practical, hands-on lessons, guiding you through the tools, techniques, and flavors that professional baristas use every day. By the end of the course, you'll be able to craft café-quality drinks from the comfort of your kitchen. Perfect for coffee lovers looking to elevate their daily brew!

lessons.title: Espresso Machine Setup
lessons.synopsis: Learn the parts and functions of your espresso machine—master the basics so you can pull a proper shot.
lessons.instructions:
1. Show how to fill the water reservoir and turn on the machine.
2. Demonstrate grinding and loading the portafilter.
3. Walk the learner through tamping and locking the portafilter.
Pull an espresso shot together.
4. Let the learner practice the full process.

Notes---
Setting up the espresso machine properly is crucial to making great coffee. Pay attention to the grind size, tamping pressure, and water levels. These factors will affect the flavor of the espresso. Encourage the learner to experiment with the grind and tamp to see how it impacts the shot. It’s normal for new users to make a few mistakes while finding the right balance, so don’t rush the process!
graduationRequirements: Can set up machine independently.

lessons.title: Pulling the Perfect Shot
lessons.synopsis: Understand the key variables to pull a balanced espresso shot.
lessons.instructions:
1. Show how to grind the coffee and tamp evenly.
2. Set the ideal shot time (25-30 seconds).
3. Watch the espresso pour, noting color and texture.
4. Let the learner pull a shot and adjust as needed.
5. Taste and discuss the results.

Notes---
A balanced shot should have rich crema and smooth flavor. The learner will start adjusting grind size, tamp pressure, and shot time to perfect this.
graduationRequirements: Can pull a shot in 25-30 seconds with proper crema.

lessons.title: Espresso Tasting and Calibration
lessons.synopsis: Learn to taste espresso and identify under, balanced, and over-extraction.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull shots with varying settings (grind size, tamp).
2. Taste and compare each shot.
3. Discuss flavor notes for under and over-extracted shots.
4. Adjust settings for a balanced shot.
5. Taste and refine based on preference.

Note---
Developing taste sensitivity takes time. Focus on body, acidity, and bitterness. Small adjustments make a big difference.
graduationRequirements: Can identify under, balanced, and over-extracted espresso.

lessons.title: Cleaning and Maintenance
lessons.synopsis: Learn the importance of regular cleaning and maintenance to keep your machine in top condition.
lessons.instructions:
1. Clean the portafilter and steam wand after use.
2. Show how to backflush the machine.
3. Explain when and how to descale the machine.
4. Let the learner clean the machine themselves.
5. Discuss how regular cleaning extends the machine’s life.


Notes:---
A clean machine produces better-tasting espresso and lasts longer. Always clean after every use.

lessons.title: Milk Steaming Basics
lessons.synopsis: Learn how to properly steam milk for espresso drinks.
lessons.instructions:
1. Show how to fill the milk jug to the right level.
2. Position the steam wand just under the surface.
3. Steam until the milk expands and reaches 140-150°F.
4. Let the learner practice steaming milk.
5. Discuss how texture impacts the drink.


Notes---
Proper microfoam is key for lattes and cappuccinos. The milk should be silky, not frothy. Steaming too hot can scald it.
graduationRequirements: Can steam milk to 140-150°F with microfoam.

lessons.title: Pouring Basic Latte Art
lessons.synopsis: Begin creating simple latte art, starting with hearts.
lessons.instructions:
1. Steam milk until smooth and silky.
2. Pull an espresso shot and prepare the cup.
3. Demonstrate pouring to create a heart shape.
4. Let the learner try pouring.
5. Refine the pour technique based on feedback.


Notes---
The art is in the pour. Begin slow, practicing height and flow rate to perfect the heart shape.
graduationRequirements: Can pour a basic heart shape with proper texture.

lessons.title: Cappuccino vs. Latte Milk Texture
lessons.synopsis: Understand the difference in milk textures for cappuccinos and lattes.
lessons.instructions:
1. Steam milk for a cappuccino, creating more froth.
2. Steam milk for a latte, focusing on smooth microfoam.
3. Compare the textures side by side.
4. Let the learner prepare both milk types.
5. Taste and discuss the difference in texture and drink experience.


Notes---
Cappuccinos are more foam-forward, while lattes are creamier. Mastering both textures is essential for crafting different drinks.

lessons.title: Making a Flat White
lessons.synopsis: Learn to prepare a flat white, a milk drink known for its velvety texture.
lessons.instructions:
- Steam milk with a focus on minimal foam.
- Pull a double shot of espresso.
- Pour the milk carefully to preserve a silky texture.
- Let the learner try to create a flat white.
- Discuss the key differences between a flat white and a latte.


Notes---
The flat white has a stronger coffee flavor due to the double shot, with just enough milk to balance it. Precision in milk steaming is key.

lessons.title: Making a Cappuccino
lessons.synopsis: Perfect the classic cappuccino with its distinct foam-to-milk ratio.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull a single or double shot of espresso.
2. Steam milk to create a thick foam.
3. Pour the milk, focusing on foam first.
4. Let the learner prepare their cappuccino.
5. Discuss how to achieve the right foam height.

Notes---
Cappuccinos should be light and airy, with a thick foam layer on top. Practice is needed to control the foam while pouring.
graduationRequirements: Can make a cappuccino with proper foam-to-milk ratio.

lessons.title: Iced Latte Basics
lessons.synopsis: Learn how to make a refreshing iced latte with cold milk and espresso.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull a shot of espresso and let it cool.
2. Fill a glass with ice.
3. Pour cold milk into the glass.
4. Add the cooled espresso shot.
5. Let the learner prepare their own iced latte.

Notes---
Iced lattes are popular in warm weather. Ensure the espresso cools slightly before adding it to the ice to avoid dilution.

lessons.title: Americano Perfection
lessons.synopsis: Master the Americano, a diluted yet strong espresso-based drink.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull a shot of espresso.
2. Boil water and fill a cup halfway.
3. Pour the espresso into the water.
4. Let the learner prepare their Americano.
5. Discuss the drink’s strength and versatility.


Notes---
The Americano offers a smoother, less intense flavor compared to straight espresso. It’s ideal for those who prefer a longer coffee drink.

lessons.title: Crafting a Cortado
lessons.synopsis: Learn to make a cortado, a balanced espresso and milk drink.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull a double shot of espresso.
2. Steam a small amount of milk (equal ratio to espresso).
3. Pour the milk to create a smooth blend.
4. Let the learner make their own cortado.
5. Discuss the balance of coffee and milk in this drink.


Notes ---
A cortado is perfect for those who prefer less milk and more coffee flavor. The key is the 1:1 espresso-to-milk ratio.

lessons.title: Advanced Latte Art – Rosetta
lessons.synopsis: Learn to pour a rosetta, one of the most advanced latte art designs.
lessons.instructions:
1. Steam milk to create smooth microfoam.
2. Pull an espresso shot and prepare the cup.
3. Demonstrate pouring to create a rosetta pattern.
4. Let the learner practice the pour.
5. Refine technique and troubleshoot common issues.

Notes:---
Rosetta requires steady hands and control over milk flow. Precision is key, and it may take multiple attempts to perfect.
graduationRequirements: Can pour a recognizable rosetta.

lessons.title: Manual Brewing Techniques – French Press
lessons.synopsis: Learn the basics of manual brewing with a French press for a full-bodied coffee experience.
lessons.instructions:
1. Measure coarse coffee grounds (1:15 ratio with water).
2. Add hot water and stir to saturate.
3. Steep for 4 minutes, then press down the plunger.
4. Pour and taste the coffee.
5. Let the learner try the brewing process.


Notes---
French press offers a more robust coffee flavor. The longer steeping process allows more oils and flavors to extract from the grounds.

lessons.title: Espresso Machine Troubleshooting
lessons.synopsis: Learn to diagnose common espresso machine issues and perform basic troubleshooting.
lessons.instructions:
1. Identify common issues (grind too fine, shot pulling too fast).
2. Adjust grind size and tamp pressure.
3. Clean the portafilter and check water flow.
4. Let the learner troubleshoot an issue with guidance.
5. Test and review the results.

Notes---
Regular machine maintenance reduces the likelihood of problems. Knowing how to troubleshoot ensures consistent shot quality.
graduationRequirements: Can adjust grind size.
Can clean the machine.

lessons.title: Signature Drink Creation
lessons.synopsis: Create a signature espresso-based drink by experimenting with flavors and techniques.
